thread.title: David Murray says Greece shows dangers of 'complacency'
thread.title_full: David Murray says Greece shows dangers of 'complacency' | afr.com

author: Primrose Riordan
title: David Murray says Greece shows dangers of 'complacency'
text:
David Murray has defended his Financial System Inquiry for bank capital, and said the Greece crisis is a warning against 'complacency' Ryan Stuart Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan Former Commonwealth head David Murray has defended his Financial System Inquiry's recommendation for international benchmarks for bank capital, saying the Greek financial crisis is a warning against complacency.
Mr Murray said the Greek crisis also demonstrated the importance of Australia keeping on top of the rising cost of welfare and the need for more effective tax regimes.
The inquiry's argument for raising bank capital levels to that of the top quarter of global banks was rejected by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority , although they embraced the call for banks to be "unquestionably strong".
Mr Murray said while he agreed with APRA that the banks were well capitalised and a financial crisis was unlikely, taxpayers needed an "extra layer of protection" as Australia could be more vulnerable at times.
"The point of the financial system inquiry report was that Australia is a capital importer and therefore it has more vulnerability at certain times than other countries".
He said this meant Australian banks needed to be strong in "global terms".
"We have to have this notion of unquestionably strong capital in global terms. So we're really saying we have to be above most of the pack," he said.
Australia banks were "well prepared for any shock" but the Greek crisis was evidence of the danger of complacency, according to Mr Murray.
 "No country can [be complacent], because if it's left too late to make adjustments, the social cost just gets too high as has being demonstrated with the closure of the banks in Greece," he said.
The Greek crisis had critical lessons for Australia's welfare and tax system, Mr Murray said.
"The Greek issue demonstrates that we have to stay on the issues of costs of pensions, cost of welfare, the tax structures - whether they are effective or not."
Mr Murray said his Financial System Inquiry's recommendation for Australian banks to lift their capital rations would shield taxpayers.
"We want to make sure in the unlikely event there is difficulty in the banking system and the taxpayer is drawn in to deal with that problem we want to make sure the taxpayer can get back out either at no cost or a profit," he said.
